t:intro.p: The AllPairsShortestPath function computes the shortest distances between all combinations of the specified source and target vertices. The function works on directed, undirected, weighted, and unweighted graphs.
The function is useful in social network analysis. The resulting pairs and distances can be aggregated to determine a closeness metric or the k-degree for each vertex in a graph.

pre.tt: SELECT * FROM AllPairsShortestPath ( ON vertices_table AS Vertices PARTITION BY vertex_key_column [,...] ON edges_table AS Edges PARTITION BY source_vertex_key_column [,...] [ ON sources_table AS Sources PARTITION BY source_vertex_key_column [,...] ] [ ON targets_table AS Targets PARTITION BY target_vertex_key_column [,...] ] USING TargetKey ({ 'target_key_column' | target_key_column_range }[,...]) [ EdgeWeight ('edge_weight') ] [ Directed ({'true'|'t'|'yes'|'y'|'1'|'false'|'f'|'no'|'n'|'0'}) ] [ MaxDistance (max_distance) ] [ GroupSize (group_size) ] ) AS alias;

div.dd: Specify the target key (the names of the Edges table columns that identify the target vertex). If you specify targets_table, the function uses only the vertices in targets_table as targets (which must be a subset of those that this syntax element specifies).
[Optional] Specify the name of the Edges table column that contains edge weights. Each edge_weight is a positive value.
Default: Each edge_weight is 1 (that is, the graph is unweighted)
[Optional] Specify whether the graph is directed.

[Optional] Specify the maximum distance between source and target for which the function outputs the vertices. The max_distance must be an integer. If max_distance is negative, the distance between source and target is unbounded.

[Optional] Specify the number of source vertices that run a single-node shortest path (SNSP) algorithm in parallel. If group_size exceeds the number of source vertices in a partition, the number of source vertices in the partition is the group size.
Default behavior: The function uses cluster and query characteristics to determine the optimal group size.

td.div: Each row represents a vertex of the graph.

Each row represents an edge of the graph.
Note: For undirected graph, this table might have duplicate rows. Remove them, using code in Deleting Duplicate Edges Table Rows.

[Required for directed graph, optional for undirected graph.] Vertices to use as sources.
By default, all vertices are both sources and targets (that is, the graph is undirected).
[Required for directed graph, optional for undirected graph.] Vertices to use as targets.
Any allowed in PARTITION BY clause
[Column appears once for each specified vertex_key_column.] All or part of unique vertex key. Cannot be NULL.
Any allowed in PARTITION BY clause
Column appears once for each specified source_vertex_key_column.] All or part of key that identifies source vertex of edge. Must be a vertex_key_column in Vertices table. Cannot be NULL.
Column appears once for each specified target_vertex_key_column.] All or part of key that identifies target vertex of edge. Must be a vertex_key_column in Vertices table. Cannot be NULL.
[Required only for weighted graph.] Edge weight, a positive value. Can be NULL.
Same as corresponding vertex_key_column in Vertices table
Column appears once for each specified source_vertex_key_column.] All or part of key that identifies source vertex of edge. Must be a vertex_key_column in Vertices table. Cannot be NULL.
Same as corresponding vertex_key_column in Vertices table
Column appears once for each specified target_vertex_key_column.] All or part of key that identifies target vertex of edge. Must be a vertex_key_column in Vertices table. Cannot be NULL.

t:intro.p: The Edges table of an undirected graph can have duplicate rows, because each edge between vertices A and B is represented by two rows—one row has A in the source column and B in the target column, and the other row has B in the source column and A in the target column. Teradata recommends deleting duplicate rows from the Edges table, using this code (where edges_table is the Edges table name):

For source and target vertices connected by a path of less than max_distance, the function outputs their corresponding source and target vertex keys and the distance of the shortest path between them. The function does not output cycle information.

td.div: Distance of shortest path between the source and target vertices.

t:intro.p: In the following figure, nodes represent persons—light blue for males and dark blue for females. The directed edges represent phone calls from one person to another. Node size represents number of connections (degree centrality).
t:intro.h4: Graph of Phone Calls between Persons
t:intro.p: The graph in the figure is represented by the Vertices and Edges tables callers and calls, respectively.

pre.tt: SELECT * FROM AllPairsShortestPath ( ON callers AS Vertices PARTITION BY callerid ON calls AS Edges PARTITION BY callerfrom USING TargetKey ('callerto') MaxDistance (-1) ) AS dt ORDER BY source, target;

t:intro.p: Download a zip file of all examples and a SQL script file that creates their input tables from the download tab in the left pane.
The input is the same as in AllPairsShortestPath Example: Unweighted, Unbounded Graph.

pre.tt: SELECT * FROM AllPairsShortestPath ( ON callers AS Vertices PARTITION BY callerid ON calls AS Edges PARTITION BY callerfrom USING TargetKey ('callerto') EdgeWeight ('calls') MaxDistance (-1) ) AS dt ORDER BY source, target;

t:intro.p: Download a zip file of all examples and a SQL script file that creates their input tables from the download tab in the left pane.
t:intro.h3: AllPairsShortestPath Example: Weighted, Bounded Graph with Sources
t:intro.p: The input is the same as in AllPairsShortestPath Example: Unweighted, Unbounded Graph.

pre.tt: SELECT * FROM AllPairsShortestPath ( ON callers AS Vertices PARTITION BY callerid ON calls AS Edges PARTITION BY callerfrom ON (SELECT callerid FROM callers WHERE callerid IN (1, 2)) AS Sources PARTITION BY callerid USING TargetKey ('callerto') MaxDistance (8) EdgeWeight ('calls') ) AS dt ORDER BY source, target;

t:intro.p: Download a zip file of all examples and a SQL script file that creates their input tables from the download tab in the left pane.
